concept.title: Attestation
concept.shortdesc: An attestation is a claim cryptographically attested by an attestor's signature. TokenScript enables wallets to create and manage attestations.

conbody.note: Unlike a blockchain token, which exists only as a concept and has no physical files, an attestation can be encoded as a DER file or encoded in a .
conbody.p: Attestation can be about anything. To individual identity, one can be attested to have the legal drinking / voting age, or an university degree, or that he owns an email address.
There can be attestations to a token. For example, an insurance company can issue an attestation attesting a specific car is insured.

There can be attestations to an activity. For example, a smart contract may allow blockchain payment redeemed on the condition that a specific job is attested as well done. Such a job can be, for example, a car painting job, identified by the job id in the corresponding Smart Contracts;

For example, if you rent a tokenized car, you want to make sure, that the seller has an insurance police on the car. And if you trade something with someone, you might want to be sure that he has verified his identity. And so on.
There are typically 3 ways to use an attestation:

ul.li: As the payload of an attested transactions. The underlying smart contract will check the validity of such attestations.
To prove something to a 3rd party. For example, you can construct a proof of your email address with an email address attestation.
To provide dependency for other attestations. Since .

conbody.p: All those cases require an attestation: A data object (or file) which proofs a claim on something. An attestor can attestate an national identity or the possession of an email address, an insurance company can attestate an insurance certificate and so on. Those files attestations are usually signed by an attestor, but in some cases can be self signed, for example when the claim is to own an address of a cryptocurrency.

A standardized attestation format has an enormous potential to smoothly integrate identity and other claims into the web and to streamline a lot of processes, like signing up for an exchange, registering a bank account, verifying as an accredited investor for an Security Token Offer.
TokenScript fully support the integration of attestation processes, triggered by an action card directly in the wallet. You can integrate an attestation circuit into the life cycle of a token.
Attestation and blockchain token, are related concepts. Both of them require the user having a private key.

In some use-cases they are interchangeable. For example, a FIFA ticket can be eiether an attestation or a blockchain token. When it is an attestation, it attests the key-holder's right to enter the venue. When it is a blockchain token, it serves the same purpose, and also might be transferable within the Smart Contract rules.

That reveals the first difference: an attestation isn't transferable, and a token's transferability depends on the smart contract. The second difference, is that attestations are private, not stored on the blockchain. The proof of an attestation, however, might be written to the blockchain in an .
[Editor's note: the following paragraph says the same as the previous, consider consolidating.]

An attestation can be connected to an Ethereum entity like the holder of a key pair. This allows to create cheques - the transfer of coins from a smart contract to someone who can provide an attestation for an identifier like an email address. Also, attestations of anything can be required to use a smart contract. You could create an ICO smart contract which requires an attestation of being a verified investor.

Another example is a car sharing platform: To offer her car on a platform, Alice has to provide an insurance attestation. She gets this attestation by using a Card in the TokenScript of her car token, which launches the insurance process straight from the wallet. Since Alice, the car sharing platform and Bob, who rents the car, all have TokenScript installed, they silently validate in each step, if Alice's car is insured.
Any delivery vs payment operation can integrate any kind of attestation which might be required for the process.

Attestations are usually offchain. They often carry private information, like identity, birth date or mobile phone number. This kind of information should never be saved on a public blockchain. Offchain attestations are data objects signed by an attestor stored on a local device. However, attestations can also be token, which don't disclose private information, but attest that an attestation was given.

Attestations can be used to create a proof of attestations which can be part of a transaction. For example, if you have a cheque smart contract the receiver needs to create a transaction which includes a proof of the attestation of the required identifier, like a phone number.
An attestation is a signed dataObject. The dataObject can contain any information, including public and private information. It can be signed by an Ethereum entity and attested to a token.
Attestations are non-transferable, but transferability can be achieved by attesting to another attestation.
Attestations can be fully expressed by an URI for easy and cross-compatible usage.
The attestation format takes close inspiration from the X.509 certificate specification, RFC-5280, but makes several fields optional, adds a few new ones and changes some formats.
There is still much work to be done. For example, we need a format that can do partial attestation by using Merkle Tree, or even zero-knowledge proof of attestation.
